chapter.title: Deploying with &deepsea;/&salt;
chapter.para: &salt; along with &deepsea; is a stack of components that help you deploy and manage server infrastructure. It is very scalable, fast, and relatively easy to get running. Read the following considerations before you start deploying the cluster with &salt;:

listitem.para: &sminion;s are the nodes controlled by a dedicated node called &smaster;. &sminion;s have roles, for example &osd;, &mon;, &mgr;, &rgw;, &igw;, or &ganesha;.

A &smaster; runs its own &sminion;. It is required for running privileged tasks—for example creating, authorizing, and copying keys to minions—so that remote minions never need to run privileged tasks.

tip.title: Sharing Multiple Roles per Server
tip.para: You will get the best performance from your &ceph; cluster when each role is deployed on a separate node. But real deployments sometimes require sharing one node for multiple roles. To avoid trouble with performance and the upgrade procedure, do not deploy the &osd;, &mds;, or &mon; role to the &adm;.

listitem.para: &sminion;s need to correctly resolve the &smaster;'s host name over the network. By default, they look for the salt host name, but you can specify any other network-reachable host name in the /etc/salt/minion file, see .

sect1.title: Introduction to &deepsea;
sect1.para: The goal of &deepsea; is to save the administrator time and confidently perform complex operations on a &ceph; cluster.
&ceph; is a very configurable software solution. It increases both the freedom and responsibility of system administrators.
The minimal &ceph; setup is good for demonstration purposes, but does not show interesting features of &ceph; that you can see with a big number of nodes.

&deepsea; collects and stores data about individual servers, such as addresses and device names. For a distributed storage system such as &ceph;, there can be hundreds of such items to collect and store. Collecting the information and entering the data manually into a configuration management tool is exhausting and error prone.

The steps necessary to prepare the servers, collect the configuration, and configure and deploy &ceph; are mostly the same. However, this does not address managing the separate functions. For day to day operations, the ability to trivially add hardware to a given function and remove it gracefully is a requirement.

&deepsea; addresses these observations with the following strategy: &deepsea; consolidates the administrator's decisions in a single file. The decisions include cluster assignment, role assignment and profile assignment. And &deepsea; collects each set of tasks into a simple goal. Each goal is a stage:

listitem.para: Stage 0—the preparation— during this stage, all required updates are applied and your system may be rebooted.

important.title: Re-run Stage 0 after the &adm; Reboot
important.para: If the &adm; reboots during stage 0 to load the new kernel version, you need to run stage 0 again, otherwise minions will not be targeted.

listitem.para: Stage 1—the discovery—here all hardware in your cluster is being detected and necessary information for the &ceph; configuration is being collected. For details about configuration, refer to .
Stage 2—the configuration—you need to prepare configuration data in a particular format.
Stage 3—the deployment—creates a basic &ceph; cluster with mandatory &ceph; services. See for their list.
Stage 4—the services—additional features of &ceph; like iSCSI, &rgw; and &cephfs; can be installed in this stage. Each is optional.

Stage 5—the removal stage. This stage is not mandatory and during the initial setup it is usually not needed. In this stage the roles of minions and also the cluster configuration are removed. You need to run this stage when you need to remove a storage node from your cluster. For details refer to .

sect2.title: Organization and Important Locations
sect2.para: &salt; has several standard locations and several naming conventions used on your master node:

listitem.para: The directory stores configuration data for your cluster minions. Pillar is an interface for providing global configuration values to all your cluster minions.
The directory stores &salt; state files (also called sls files). State files are formatted descriptions of states in which the cluster should be.
The directory stores Python scripts known as runners. Runners are executed on the master node.
The directory stores Python scripts that are called modules. The modules are applied to all minions in your cluster.
The directory is used by &deepsea;. Collected configuration data are stored here.

A directory used by &deepsea;. It stores sls files that can be in different formats, but each subdirectory contains sls files. Each subdirectory contains only one type of sls file. For example, /srv/salt/ceph/stage contains orchestration files that are executed by salt-run state.orchestrate.

sect1.title: &deepsea; CLI
sect1.para: &deepsea; also provides a command line interface (CLI) tool that allows the user to monitor or run stages while visualizing the execution progress in real-time. Verify that the deepsea-cli package is installed before you run the deepsea executable.
Two modes are supported for visualizing a stage's execution progress:

listitem.para: Monitoring mode: visualizes the execution progress of a &deepsea; stage triggered by the salt-run command issued in another terminal session.
Stand-alone mode: runs a &deepsea; stage while providing real-time visualization of its component steps as they are executed.

important.title: &deepsea; CLI Commands
important.para: The &deepsea; CLI commands can only be run on the &smaster; node with the &rootuser; privileges.

sect3.title: Role Assignment
sect3.para: This section provides you with details on assigning 'roles' to your cluster nodes. A 'role' in this context means the service you need to run on the node, such as &mon;, &ogw;, or &igw;. No role is assigned automatically, only roles added to policy.cfg will be deployed.
The assignment follows this pattern:
Where the items have the following meaning and values:

listitem.para: ROLE_NAME is any of the following: 'master', 'admin', 'mon', 'mgr', 'storage', 'mds', 'igw', 'rgw', 'ganesha', 'grafana', or 'prometheus'.
PATH is a relative directory path to .sls or .yml files. In case of .sls files, it usually is cluster, while .yml files are located at stack/default/ceph/minions.

FILES_TO_INCLUDE are the &salt; state files or YAML configuration files. They normally consist of &sminion;s' host names, for example ses5min2.yml. Shell globbing can be used for more specific matching.

sect2.title: &drvgrps;
sect2.para: An administrator should manually specify a group of OSDs that are interrelated (hybrid OSDs that are deployed on solid state and spinners) or share the same deployment options (identical, for example same object store, same encryption option, stand-alone OSDs). To avoid explicitly listing devices, &drvgrps; use a list of filter items that correspond to a few selected fields of ceph-volume's inventory reports. In the simplest case this could be the 'rotational' flag (all solid-state drives are to be db_devices, all rotating ones data devices) or something more involved such as 'model' strings, or sizes. &deepsea; will provide code that translates these &drvgrps; into actual device lists for inspection by the user.

'10G:40G' - Includes disks whose size is within the range.
':10G' - Includes disks less than or equal to 10 GB in size.
'40G:' - Includes disks equal to or greater than 40 GB in size.

example.title: Matching by Disk Size
example.screen: drive_group_default: target: '*' data_devices: size: '40TB:' db_devices: size: ':2TB'

note.title: Quotes Required
note.para: When using the ':' delimiter, you need to enclose the size in quotes, otherwise the ':' sign will be interpreted as a new configuration hash.

tip.title: Unit Shortcuts
tip.para: Instead of (G)igabytes, you can specify the sizes in (M)egabytes or (T)erabytes as well.

sect3.title: Examples
sect3.para: This section includes examples of different OSD setups.

example.title: Simple Setup
example.para: This example describes two nodes with the same setup:
The corresponding drive_groups.yml file will be as follows:
example.screen: drive_group_default: target: '*' data_devices: model: SSD-123-foo db_devices: model: MC-55-44-XZ
example.para: Such a configuration is simple and valid. The problem is that an administrator may add disks from different vendors in the future, and these will not be included. You can improve it by reducing the filters on core properties of the drives:
example.screen: drive_group_default: target: '*' data_devices: rotational: 1 db_devices: rotational: 0
example.para: In the previous example, we are enforcing all rotating devices to be declared as 'data devices' and all non-rotating devices will be used as 'shared devices' (wal, db).
If you know that drives with more than 2 TB will always be the slower data devices, you can filter by size:
example.screen: drive_group_default: target: '*' data_devices: size: '2TB:' db_devices: size: ':2TB'

example.title: Advanced Setup
example.para: This example describes two distinct setups: 20 HDDs should share 2 SSDs, while 10 SSDs should share 2 NVMes.
Such a setup can be defined with two layouts as follows:
example.screen: drive_group: target: '*' data_devices: rotational: 0 db_devices: model: MC-55-44-XZ
drive_group_default: target: '*' data_devices: model: MC-55-44-XZ db_devices: vendor: samsung size: 256GB

example.title: Advanced Setup with Non-uniform Nodes
example.para: The previous examples assumed that all nodes have the same drives. However, that is not always the case:
You can use the 'target' key in the layout to target specific nodes. &salt; target notation helps to keep things simple:
example.screen: drive_group_node_one_to_five: target: 'node[1-5]' data_devices: rotational: 1 db_devices: rotational: 0
drive_group_the_rest: target: 'node[6-10]' data_devices: model: MC-55-44-XZ db_devices: model: SSD-123-foo

example.title: Expert Setup
example.para: All previous cases assumed that the WALs and DBs use the same device. It is however possible to deploy the WAL on a dedicated device as well:
example.screen: drive_group_default: target: '*' data_devices: model: MC-55-44-XZ db_devices: model: SSD-123-foo wal_devices: model: NVME-QQQQ-987

example.title: Complex (and Unlikely) Setup
example.para: In the following setup, we are trying to define:

listitem.para: 2 HDDs backed by 1 SSD(db) and 1 NVMe(wal)
1 HDD is spare and should not be deployed

example.para: The summary of used drives follows:
The &drvgrps; definition will be the following:
example.screen: drive_group_hdd_nvme: target: '*' data_devices: rotational: 0 db_devices: model: NVME-QQQQ-987
drive_group_hdd_ssd_nvme: target: '*' data_devices: rotational: 0 db_devices: model: MC-55-44-XZ wal_devices: model: NVME-QQQQ-987
drive_group_ssd_nvme: target: '*' data_devices: model: SSD-123-foo db_devices: model: NVME-QQQQ-987
drive_group_ssd_standalone_encrypted: target: '*' data_devices: model: SSD-123-foo encryption: True
example.para: One HDD will remain as the file is being parsed from top to bottom.

sect2.title: Adjusting ceph.conf with Custom Settings
sect2.para: If you need to put custom settings into the ceph.conf configuration file, see for more details.
